layman:
**Chief complaint:** Nausea.  

**History of present illness:** A 28‑year‑old man who had gastric bypass surgery almost a year ago. He has lost about 200 pounds and was doing well until yesterday evening around 7–8 p.m. He started feeling nauseous and had pain in the upper right side of his belly that spread toward his right side and back. He feels like he was vomiting but has not. He feels generally unwell and has a low‑grade fever of 100.3 °F. He has never had similar symptoms before. His last normal bowel movement was yesterday. He does not have chills or blood in his stool.  

**Past medical history:** High blood pressure and severe obesity, both now resolved.  

**Past surgical history:** Gastric bypass in December 2007.  

**Medications:** Multivitamins and calcium.  

**Allergies:** None.  

**Family history:** Father had diabetes (deceased).  

**Social history:** No tobacco or alcohol use. Works a computer job.  

**Review of systems:** No other problems.  

**Physical exam:**  
- Temperature 100.3 °F, blood pressure 129/59, breathing 16/min, heart rate 84.  
- He is drowsy but can be awakened easily and talks normally. He knows who he is, where he is, and why he is here.  
- Head is normal shape, no head injury.  
- Eyes are not yellow.  
- Mouth is a little dry.  
- Neck is flexible and looks normal.  
- Breathing is normal and clear.  
- Heart beats at a regular rate.  
- Abdomen is soft. He has tenderness in the upper right part of his belly, worse in one spot, but no sharp pain or guarding. No enlarged organs, lumps, or hernias.  
- Limbs are normal, no swelling. Pulses in the back of his lower legs are normal.  
- No obvious neurological problems.  

**Lab results:**  
- White blood cells 8.4 k/µL with 79 % neutrophils.  
- Hematocrit 41 %.  
- Electrolytes normal.  
- Bilirubin 2.8 mg/dL.  
- AST 349 U/L, ALT 186 U/L, alkaline phosphatase 138 U/L.  
- Lipase 239 U/L (normal).  

**Assessment:** Gallstones in the common bile duct, possibly gallbladder inflammation.  

**Plan:** He will be admitted and given IV antibiotics. An ultrasound will be done this morning. He will likely need his gallbladder removed, probably with an intraoperative cholangiogram. The goal is to remove the stone. Because of his anatomy, an ERCP would be very hard or impossible unless assisted laparoscopically. Dr. X will see him later this morning to discuss the plan. The patient understands.
